list_definition.definition: the brother of a person’s father or mother, or the husband of an aunt

list_ex_of_english: I was lucky enough to get £1,000 of his uncle's money.
We have seen our fathers, our uncles, and other relatives come out from the mines in the prime years of life.
The rest lived with more distant relatives such as uncles and aunts, nephews and nieces or cousins.
Their fathers, their uncles, their grandfathers had all been sailors.
In particular, coreless (' no family ') households made it their duty : unmarried or widowed siblings, nephews and uncles, and so on, lived together in their latter days.
In my uncle's case, the hospital did not countenance any dose of morphine that might shorten his life, even by the smallest amount.
After 1915, he was invited to fill some of his uncle's engagements.
There was an average of 6 to 7 members per household, which could include grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins and live-in household help.
